headline: Chicken Makhani (Indian Butter Chicken)
description: This butter chicken recipe, or chicken makhani, is a favorite Indian dish that features a full-flavored sauce with spices that complement chicken.

video.description: See how to make a simple, flavorful Indian recipe in just minutes.
video.name: Chicken Makhani (Indian Butter Chicken)

name: Chicken Makhani (Indian Butter Chicken)
recipeIngredient: 1 pinch salt and ground black pepper to taste
1 pound boneless, skinless chicken thighs, cut into bite-size pieces
0.25 teaspoon cayenne pepper, or to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Heat 1 tablespoon oil in a large saucepan over medium-high heat. Saut√© shallot and onion until soft and translucent, about 5 minutes.

Stir in butter, ginger-garlic paste, lemon juice, 1 teaspoon garam masala, chili powder, cumin, and bay leaf. Cook and stir for 1 minute. Add tomato sauce, and cook for 2 minutes, continuing to frequently stir.
Stir in half-and-half and yogurt. Reduce heat to low, and simmer for 10 minutes, frequently stirring. Season with salt and pepper. Remove from heat and set aside.
Heat remaining 1 tablespoon oil in a large heavy skillet over medium heat. Cook chicken until lightly browned, about 10 minutes.

Reduce heat, and season with remaining 1 teaspoon garam masala and cayenne. Stir in a few spoonfuls of sauce, and simmer until liquid has reduced, and chicken is no longer pink. Add cooked chicken into sauce and stir together.
Dissolve cornstarch into water, then mix into the sauce. Cook for 5 to 10 minutes, or until thickened.

review.reviewBody: Loved this - made as posted. I topped with chopped cilantro. I also made naan out of canned biscuit dough- very easy, just flatten, and fry slowly in a cast iron pan.
Amazing.
My family and I looked it. We are not, however, Indian food aficionados. Will make it again.

Excellent homemade version! My husband loved it, will definitely make this again.

It was delicious. I read the other reviews so added a bit more spices and added dry coriander. Used fresh garlic and ginger and served with fresh coriander on top. Creamy and tasty dish on rice especially tasty with warm naan to mop up the sauce

I loved this and so did my husband which surprised me. I didn't have much onion so I added my green onions too. I used 1/2 full cream and half water. I also used 4 garlic cloves and a bunch of fresh grated garlic. For the tomato puree I used a 6oz can of tomato paste and then added some water. I was very happy with it. It was plenty of sauce and I probably had a lot more chicken. I didn't add the corn starch in the water. I just sprinkled some of the corn starch on the chicken as it was cooking and added water as needed. Our family loves the sauce and there was plenty. Served over rice. I used the same pan for both items. I just took the sauce out and put in a bowl while I cooked the chicken.

This recipe is very delicious, even better the following day! I made it last week, and I am making it again tonight. Thank you for a great recipe! For those who think the coriander is missing, it is not, as it is already in the garam masala. I followed the recipe to a 'T' and found the balance to be perfect! Okay, I did cut back on the cream and butter, I used coconut cream due to my dairy allergy, so I would recommend adding both according to your taste. I always make up my garam masala fresh using a recipe online. I used an immersion blender to smooth out and cream my sauce. I also whizzed in some of my cooked rice to get to the desired thickness of my sauce.
I LOVED this recipe. Really delicious. Wish I had some naan because I had a lot of sauce. Great over rice. Comfort Indian Food!

I took 1 star away because I made changes to the recipe. I used 2tbs each of garlic and ginger paste. I added 1tsp of ground coriander to the sauce and another tsp to the chicken. After stirring in half & half (I actually used heavy whipping cream) and the yogurt, I ran the sauce through a blender for smoother texture and then returned to the stove to simmer for 10 minutes. I used ground cashews instead of cornstarch. I made this recipe before without the coriander and cashews. The flavor of this dish is definitely better with the coriander and cashews added. I serve this with basmati rice.

This Chicken Makhani dish was great. Easy to make (January 2022) without having to purchase a lot of ingredients I'd normally not use. Mine turned out thick enough I didn't have to use the cornstarch to thicken. Served on rice with a broccoli side. :)

I‚Äôm from the Caribbean, I‚Äôve never eaten this before so I have no idea how it supposed to taste however, this was delicious. My family loved it. I used fresh garlic and ginger, corn starch was needed. I marinated the chicken before I cooked it. Thank you for sharing this easy recipe.

Double the butter and replace the half-and-half with heavy cream. (double cream would be ideal, but it's hard to find in the US)
Also, it might be blasphemy, but I made this with filet mignon instead of chicken thighs a couple times (making sure the filet was medium rare) and it was INSANELY good.

Quite good with easy to follow instructions. Using what I had on hand, I subbed Korean chile flakes and New Mexico chile powder for the suggested chile powders. I added approx 2 tsp of demarara sugar to tone down the tanginess. Did not need to use thickener.
This dish came out Awesome, very fast to prepare and the family absolutely loved it. Serve with sour cream, Cilantro, and a lemon wedge. Will make again!!
Indian Butter Chicken is one of my favorite Indian dishes! I'd love to try it on a pizza!!!
made two batches on mild and on very hot both was very good
Turned out beautifully! No adjustments to the recipe were necessary!

I loved this sauce! Goes with any protein or chick peas. I even used it with shrimp. I‚Äôm obsessed with it. I could eat at by itself!

This thickened the sauce without having to use corn starch. As another reviewer suggested, I also used an immersion blender to make the sauce smooth before adding the chicken. My whole family enjoyed this dish and we'll definitely have it again!

Best recipe ever. It never fails to please. I make this as often as I can. 

If you want to tone it down, use dark chili powder instead of regular chili powder.

Also, use cashew powder as a thickener instead of cornstarch.

Or, use slightly watered down tomato paste in place of the tomato puree. The sauce will be naturally thick.
Amazing recipe- I add more shallots and don't add the cornstarch (not needed), I have gotten so many compliments, its my go-to for company meals!

I loved the recipe definitely. I will must attempt it at my home. Thank you for such decent sharing.

My first time trying Indian! Really enjoyed the recipe. I didn't have 1/2 and 1/2, so I used heavy cream, and added some water. I did not need to use the cornstarch thickener, due to this. I did add more spices during the simmering phase, and it was a mistake. The taste was chalky. I suppose you must heat the spices with the oil/butter first, because when I added extra later, it changed the texture. Next time, I will stick to the recipe, or make my changes to spices during the saute stage! Thank you!

And as another review suggested, I ran the sauce through my food processor at the end to smooth out the remaining onions, I prefer smoother sauces. This is a new household favorite!

This was my first time making this. Easy to make and it tasted really good. My family liked it and it's getting added to the "we will eat it again" list.

I used cumin seeds adding at the beginning with onions and shallot. I found the sauce was thick enough without adding corn starch. This was delicious! My wife loved it.
Great!

So this is very similar to another butter chicken recipe that I've created, so I wanted to try it. I also love to add potatoes and bell peppers to mine for that extra bit of flavor and fullness. It's a huge hit in my house!

Awesome recipe!

 It‚Äôs easy to make and taste great! Everybody at home loved the dish!

Did this twice, and both times the sauce seemed to break after I added the yogurt. I've not done much with yogurt so I don't know if what happened is normal or if I should be doing something different.

I usually buy jarred Indian simmer sauces, but we‚Äôre now living abroad and can‚Äôt find a lot of my go to shortcuts. This recipe was a hit with the kids. Thanks for helping me make a familiar dinner in unfamiliar surroundings.

I used three tablespoons of the ginger garlic paste instead, and added one teaspoon of coriander as well. Also replaced the cornstarch with a quarter cup of ground cashews (I love it whenever I can get use out of my mortar and pestle!) and served over rice. So delicious! I will definitely be making this again.

***DAIRY FREE MODIFICATIONS**** I marinated the chicken overnight in a bit of coconut milk yogurt, lime juice, cumin, and coriander. I cooked the chicken first with olive oil and then removed it from the skillet. I then chopped an onion and saut√©ed until translucent in leftover juice from chicken and 1-2 tbsp dairy free butter, added a rough approximation of 3tbsp of garlic and 3tbsp ginger, 1 tsp coriander, 1 tsp garam masala, 1 tsp cumin, 1/2 tsp cayenne pepper and 1 bay leaf and let that cook for approx 1 minute. Then added 1 cup pur√©ed tomato, 1 cup coconut milk, 1/4 cup coconut milk yogurt and let that simmer for 2-3 minutes before adding chicken back in. I‚Äôm currently still cooking, but the sauce tastes so good I had to write a review! Planning on eating with basmati rice and garlic & herb naan ??

Very good dish. Absolutely delicious. I doubled it so we would have leftovers. I made it exactly as the recipe described and it was out of this world delicious.

Use fresh ginger and garlic (about 5 cloves of garlic, and about 1 inch of ginger, peeled and minced). If you have a food processor, that will dice up the cashews enough to sub out the corn starch. This is truly restaurant grade Chicken Makhani once you get the mix right.

After reading some reviews, I made quite a few changes when it came to the spices in the recipe.
